full_citation: Kelly, A. E., & Goulden, M. L. (2008). Rapid shifts in plant distribution with recent climate change. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 105(33), 11823-11826.
lapse_rate: provided in study: 0.73 C / 100 m
extraction_notes: data for mean elevation shift reported in main text
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: "the mean temperatures in the climate regions straddled by the transect increased by 0.63 C during the study period..The average temperature lapse rate in the area is 0.0073çC/m (Table S1), implying an upward shift of meantemperature of 56 m (Table 2)."

full_citation: Freeman, B. G., Scholer, M. N., Ruiz-Gutierrez, V., & Fitzpatrick, J. W. (2018). Climate change causes upslope shifts and mountaintop extirpations in a tropical bird community. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 115(47), 11982-11987.
lapse_rate: provided in study: 0.51 C / 100 m
extraction_notes: data for elevational limits (from all data sources) presented in Table S3, data for mean elevation shifts (from mist-netting data only) presented in Table S2. Note different sample sizes for different metrics (N = 108 for limits & N = 65 for mean elevation shifts)
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Temperature change estimated using CRU data; authors report a local lapse rate of 0.51 C decrease in temperature per 100 m elevation; this equates to an expected upslope shift of 75 m

full_citation: Freeman, B. G., & Freeman, A. M. C. (2014). Rapid upslope shifts in New Guinean birds illustrate strong distributional responses of tropical montane species to global warming. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 111(12), 4490-4494.
lapse_rate: provided in study: 0.51 C / 100 m
extraction_notes: data taken from Table S1 which provides species-level information
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Temperature changes calculated using CRU data; Expected shift reported in text using locally measured lapse rate for Mt. Karimui ( 0.51 C decrease in temperature per 100 m elevation)

full_citation: Sheldon, A. L. (2012). Possible climate-induced shift of stoneflies in a southern Appalachian catchment. Freshwater Science, 31(3), 765-774.
lapse_rate: provided in study: 0.53 - 0.70 C / 100 m (used midpoint = 0.615 C / 100 m)
extraction_notes: data for elevation shifts reported in Table 2
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Author reports changes in temperature within the study region, and describe the expected shift as 100 - 140 m upslope; I report the midpoint value of 120 m expected shift. Author used lapse rates reported from this region of 0.53 to 0.7 C decrease per 100 m increase in elevation.

full_citation: Rumpf, S. B., H_lber, K., Klonner, G., Moser, D., Sch_tz, M., Wessely, J., ... & Dullinger, S. (2018). Range dynamics of mountain plants decrease with elevation. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 115(8), 1848-1853.
lapse_rate: provided in study: 0.6 C / 100 m
extraction_notes: data for range shifts at optimum elevation (here reported as "mean elevation") reported in Table S1
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Authors report temperature increase of 0.8 C in mean annual temperature & a lapse rate of 0.6 C / 100 m

full_citation: Forero-Medina, G., Terborgh, J., Socolar, S. J., & Pimm, S. L. (2011). Elevational ranges of birds on a tropical montane gradient lag behind warming temperatures. PLoS One, 6(12), e28535.
lapse_rate: provided in study: 0.52 C / 100 m
extraction_notes: data for mean elevation shift reported in main text
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Authors calculated slope of temp change at site from 1952 to 2001, then multiplied the estimated change in temp per year by the number of years between original survey and resurvey. Expected shift reported in text using locally measured lapse rate; authors report the lapse rate as as 0.52 C decrease in temperature per 100 m elevation

full_citation: Kopp, C. W., & Cleland, E. E. (2014). Shifts in plant species elevational range limits and abundances observed over nearly five decades in a western North America mountain range._Journal of Vegetation Science,_25(1), 135-146.
lapse_rate: provided in study: 0.59 C / 100 m
extraction_notes: data extracted from Figure 4 which presents abundances -- elevational limits extracted as lowest & highest elevations where species had density > 0. I summarized elevational limits across all three soil types - hence Kopp & Cleland discuss how Artemisia has expanded at its upper elevation limits from 3500 to 3650 m on granite soils, but, because this species was historically found up to 3650 m on quartzite soils, I code this species as not having any overall shift at its upper elevation limit
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Authors report temperature change at this site & also present the expectation that a 1 degree C increase corresponds to a 167 m upslope shift (so a 0.98 C increase corresponds to a 163.66 m upslope shift)

full_citation: Menendez, R., Gonzalez-Megas, A., Jay-Robert, P., & Marquez Ferrando, R. (2014). Climate change and elevational range shifts: evidence from dung beetles in two E uropean mountain ranges. Global Ecology and Biogeography, 23(6), 646-657.
lapse_rate: provided in study: 0.52 C / 100 m
extraction_notes: data for species' shifts in Table S3
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: This value is the average of changes in temperature from three weather stations in each region. Expected shift based on warming = 205 m. Authors report local lapse rate as a decline of 0.52 C per 100 m increase in elevation

full_citation: Bassler, C., Hothorn, T., Brandl, R., & M_ller, J. (2013). Insects overshoot the expected upslope shift caused by climate warming. Plos One, 8(6), e65842.
lapse_rate: provided in study: 0.59 C / 100 m
extraction_notes: data for upper elevation shifts presented in Table S1
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Authors report a range of expected range shifts. The point estimate of 50 m (using one historic year and one modern year) is the least believable metric, as the historic year (1903) was abnormally warm and the modern year (2006) abnormally cold. The authors consider different ranges of years (5+) for historic and modern temperatures yields expectations between 130 m and 201 m upslope shift. Here I report the midpoint of this more believable range (= 165 m). Authors report the regional lapse rate as as 0.59 C decrease in temperature per 100 m elevation

full_citation: Rowe, R. J., Finarelli, J. A., & Rickart, E. A. (2010). Range dynamics of small mammals along an elevational gradient over an 80 year interval. Global Change Biology, 16(11), 2930-2943.
lapse_rate: provided in study: 0.5 - 0.98 C / 100 m (used midpoint of 0.74 C / 100 m)
extraction_notes: data for elevational limit shifts presented in Figure 4, extracted using WebPlotDigitizer
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Authors report overall temperature change at state level as 1.11 C increase. They also consider local temperature changes and report that temperatures (particularly summer maximum temperatures) have increased most at low elevations. In Results, the authors also consider various changes in seasonal temperatures (winter, summer). Authors consider a range of lapse rates, from 0.5 to 0.98 C declines per 100 m increase in elevation. They use these to predict increases in range margins at low elevations of 136 - 266 m and at high elevations of 103 - 202 m. The midpoint of these estimates is an expected increase of 177 m.

full_citation: Molina Martinez, A., Leon-Cortes, J. L., Regan, H. M., Lewis, O. T., Navarrete, D., Caballero, U., & Luis Martinez, A. (2016). lapse_rate: provided in study: 0.52 C / 100 m
extraction_notes: data for species shifts reported in Table S1
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Authors report that temperatures increased by 1.3 C overall; 1.8 C below 1000 m and .98 above 1000 m. I focus on changes in species found largely above 1000 m so report the 0.98 figure. Authors note this equates to an expected 190 m upslope shift. Authors report local lapse rate as a decline of 0.52 C per 100 m increase in elevation

full_citation: Angelo, C. L., & Daehler, C. C. (2013). Upward expansion of fire adapted grasses along a warming tropical elevation gradient. Ecography, 36(5), 551-559.
lapse_rate: provided in study: 0.30 C / 100 m
extraction_notes: data for elevational limit shifts presented in Figures 5 and 6, extracted using WebPlotDigitizer
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Temperature change calculated as difference in mean annual temperature at multiple sites near study area; observed temperature change noted to equate to an expected upslope shift of 233 - 300 m (lapse rate below 1500 m on Big Island of Hawaii noted as 0.3 C decrease in temperature per 100 m elevation). I used the midpoint of this range as the expected shift (= 267 m)

extraction_notes: data for shift at species' upper limits reported in Table 1

full_citation: Kirchman, J. J., & Van Keuren, A. E. (2017). Altitudinal range shifts of birds at the southern periphery of the boreal forest: 40 years of change in the Adirondack Mountains. The Wilson Journal of Ornithology, 129(4), 742-753.
lapse_rate: provided in study: 0.58 C / 100 m
extraction_notes: data for shifts at mean elevation and elevational limits reported in Table 1
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Average daily minimum temperature at this site has risen 2.46 C over this timespan, while average daily maximum temperature at this site has risen 1.88 C over this timespan. I used the midpoint of these two metrics = 2.18 C. Authors calculate that this amount of warming equates to an upslope shift of 324 and 424 m for maximum and minimum temperatures (=374 m expected shift for midpoint of max and min temp increases). Lapse rate given as decline of 0.58 C per increase of 100 m elevation.

full_citation: Chen, I. C., Shiu, H. J., Benedick, S., Holloway, J. D., Chey, V. K., Barlow, H. S., ... & Thomas, C. D. (2009). Elevation increases in moth assemblages over 42 years on a tropical mountain. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 106(5), 1479-1483.
lapse_rate: expected shifts provided by Chen et al. 2011
species_level_data: yes (see Wu et al. 2019 Nature Communications)
extraction_notes: data for mean elevation shift reported in main text
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: "Regional warming for the 5ç cell in which Mt. Kinabalu lies (Methods) was 0.7 çC over the 42-year period. Mean annual temperature anomalies (compared with 1961_1990 mean) for the decades before the 2 surveys (1956_1965 and 1998_2007) were 0.202 çC and 0.478 çC, respectively, showing a warming of 0.68 çC in 42 years. We also regressed annual temperature anomalies against year for the period 1956 to 2007 (coefficient 0.017, r2 0.55), which gave an estimate of 0.71 çC over 42 years. Lapse rates for the moist tropics are likely to be 0.55 çC reduction in temperature per 100-m increase in altitude (22). At this lapse rate, 0.7 çC regional warming would be equivalent to an upwards shift of 127 m."

temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Estimated temperature change is the midpoint of change in max temp and change in min temp at this site. No information on lapse rate presented.

full_citation: DeLuca, W. V., & King, D. I. (2017). Montane birds shift downslope despite recent warming in the northern Appalachian Mountains. Journal of Ornithology, 158(2), 493-505.
lapse_rate: used lapse rate of 0.58 C / 100 m reported by Kirchman & van Keruren 2017 for nearby site
extraction_notes: data presented for shifts at both elevational limits and mean elevation in Table 2; I analyze only the set of 11 species of montane birds for which the author's modern point counts encompass the species' elevational range
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Authors use the rate of warming (0.07 C / decade) observed at the mid elevation station on Mt Washington to estimate temperature changes in the White Mountains. No information on lapse rate presented.

full_citation: Neate-Clegg, M. H., Jones, S. E., Burdekin, O., Jocque, M., & Sekercioglu, C. H. (2018). Elevational changes in the avian community of a Mesoamerican cloud forest park. Biotropica, 50(5), 805-815.
lapse_rate: used lapse rate of 0.52 C / 100 m reported by Molina-Martinez et al. 2016 for nearby site
extraction_notes: data for species' elevation shifts reported as per-year rates in Table 2; multiplied by 10 to get overall shifts for the study period
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Via personal communication with M. Neate-Clegg:the increase in temperature at this site is 0.18 C / decade (data to estimate this rate of change comes from CRU). No information on lapse rate presented

full_citation: Moret, P., Aruz, M. D. L., Gobbi, M., & Barragon. (2016). Climate warming effects in the tropical Andes: first evidence for upslope shifts of Carabidae (Coleoptera) in Ecuador. Insect Conservation and Diversity, 9(4), 342-350.
lapse_rate: used lapse rate of 0.52 C / 100 m reported by Forero-Medina et al. 2011 for nearby site
extraction_notes: data for elevational limit shifts presented in Figure 4, extracted using WebPlotDigitizer
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: No values for temperature given in this study. I therefore extracted mean annual temperatures from CRU for the grid cell containing Pichincha. I calculated historic mean temperature as the mean of the years 1984, 1985 and 1986 ( = 15.43 C; I did not go further back because 1983 was an abnormally hot El Ni_o year) and modern mean temperature as the mean of the years 2012, 2013 and 2014 ( = 15.73 C), such that the estimated temperature increase over the study period is 0.3 C. No information on lapse rate presented.

full_citation: Campos-Cerqueira, M., Arendt, W. J., Wunderle Jr, J. M., & Aide, T. M. (2017). Have bird distributions shifted along an elevational gradient on a tropical mountain?. Ecology and evolution, 7(23), 9914-9924.

temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Authors report an overall increase in temperatures across California of 0.6 C during this time period (temperature increase noted to be spatially consistent across state). They also report changes in precipitation, and predict downhill shifts of ~ 85 m for optimum elevations when combining both changes in temperature and in precipitation, a prediction that fits with their observed results. Authors do not directly report lapse rates for temperature within California.

full_citation: Forister, M. L., McCall, A. C., Sanders, N. J., Fordyce, J. A., Thorne, J. H., OêBrien, J., ... & Shapiro, A. M. (2010). Compounded effects of climate change and habitat alteration shift patterns of butterfly diversity. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 107(5), 2088-2092.
lapse_rate: used lapse rate of 0.59 C / 100 m reported by Kopp & Cleland 2014 for nearby site
extraction_notes: authors shared species-level data with species identity anonymized (sp1, sp2, etc)
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Elevational shifts estimated for species using data from four site (abbreviations = RC, LC, DP and CP) and slopes in temperature are reported for each of these sites in the supplemental information. Reported slopes with average max temperature and time are: RC = 0.027, LC = -0.012, DP = 0.10 & CP = 0.02. Hence the mean slope for average max temperature and time for these four sites taken together = 0.03375. Over 21 year period = increase in max temp of 0.71. For min temperature and time the slopes are: RC = 0.035, LC = 0.058, DP = .053 & CP = 0.076. Hence the mean slope for average min temperature and time for these four sites taken together is 0.055. Over 21 year period = increase in min temp of 1.17. Midpoint of increases in max and min temp over 21 year period is then 0.093 C. Lapse rate not reported

full_citation: Kusrini, M. D., Lubis, M. I., Endarwin, W., Yazid, M., Darmawan, B., Ul-Hasanah, A. U., ... & Nasir, D. M. (2017). Elevation range shift after 40 years: The amphibians of Mount Gede Pangrango National Park revisited. Biological conservation, 206, 75-84.
lapse_rate: used lapse rate of 0.55 C / 100 m reported by Chen et al. 2009 for Borneo (which was itself an assumed lapse rate based on general expectations for humid tropical mountains)
extraction_notes: data for species presences/absences at different sites presented in Table 3
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Temperature increase at local site not reported in paper. So I extracted mean annual temperatures for grid cell containing Gede-Pangrango using CRU data. Historic mean annual temperature was 24.85 (mean of mean of each year: 1961, 1962, 1963, and 1964); modern mean annual temperature was 25.83 (mean of mean of each year: 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007). No information on lapse rate available.

lapse_rate: used lapse rate of 0.5 C / 100 m reported by Jump et al. 2012 (from Taiwan; no data from Himalaya in this dataset, this value is consistent with published estimates of lapse rate for Himalaya)
extraction_notes: data for mean elevation shift reported in Table 1; note that I calculated shifts using the species-level data presented in Table 1 which differ slightly from what is reported in the text in Results
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: 0.6 C increase per decade (!) reported in text for this region. Given that there is a mean time difference of 40 years between historic and modern periods, this equates to 2.4 C increase. No information on lapse rate reported.

full_citation: Barrows, C. W., Sweet, L. C., Rangitsch, J., Lalumiere, K., Green, T., Heacox, S., ... & Rodgers, J. E. (2020). Responding to increased aridity: Evidence for range shifts in lizards across a 50-year time span in Joshua Tree National Park. Biological Conservation, 248, 108667.
lapse_rate: used lapse rate of 0.73 C / 100 m reported by Kelly & Goulden 2008 from a nearby site
extraction_notes: data presented in Table 1
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Change in mean annual temperature described in Results (section 3.1)

full_citation: Tiberti, R., Mangiacotti, M., & Bennati, R. The upward elevational shifts of pond breeding amphibians following climate warming. Biological Conservation, 253, 108911.
lapse_rate: used lapse rate of 0.60 C / 100 m reported by Rumpf et al. 2018 for a nearby site
extraction_notes: data presented in Results
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Changes in temperature at this site plotted in Figure 2 - I used WebPlotDigitizer to extract values of temperature for start (2005) and end (2019) of study from smoothed trendline (8.42 vs. 8.94 C, respectively)

full_citation: Nooten, S. S., & Rehan, S. M. (2020). Historical changes in bumble bee body size and range shift of declining species. Biodiversity and Conservation, 29(2), 451-467.
lapse_rate: used lapse rate of 0.58 C / 100 m reported by Kirchman & van Keruren 2017 for nearby site
extraction_notes: data presented in Table 2
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Changes in temperature in this region during timeperiod reported in Discussion; authors note that they were unable to accont for sampling biases between time periods and so estimates of elevational range change should be interprted cautiously

full_citation: Geppert, C., Perazza, G., Wilson, R. J., Bertolli, A., Prosser, F., Melchiori, G., & Marini, L. (2020). Consistent population declines but idiosyncratic range shifts in Alpine orchids under global change. Nature communications,_11(1), 1-11.
lapse_rate: authors report that species are expected to shift 3.8 - 5.5 m/year to track warming; I used the midpoint of this range
extraction_notes: data extracted using WebPlotDigitizer from Figure 3
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Author report change in temperature over 29 year time window comprising the years of this study to be 0.75 C; I used 0.48 of this value as the estimated temperature change over the 14 years duration between historic and modern sampling periods

full_citation: Marshall, L., Perdijk, F., Dendoncker, N., Kunin, W., Roberts, S., & Biesmeijer, J. C. (2020). Bumblebees moving up: shifts in elevation ranges in the Pyrenees over 115 years. Proceedings of the Royal Society B, 287(1938), 20202201.
lapse_rate: used lapse rate of 0.52 C / 100 m reported by Menendez et al. 2014 for nearby site
extraction_notes: data extracted from Figure 3 using WebPlotDigitizer
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Authors report change in temperature for this area over this time period

full_citation: Marshall, L., Perdijk, F., Dendoncker, N., Kunin, W., Roberts, S., & Biesmeijer, J. C. (2020). Bumblebees moving up: shifts in elevation ranges in the Pyrenees over 115 years. Proceedings of the Royal Society B, 287(1938), 20202201.
lapse_rate: used lapse rate of 0.52 C / 100 m reported by Menendez et al. 2014 for nearby site
extraction_notes: data extracted from Figure 3 using WebPlotDigitizer

full_citation: Telleria, J. L. (2019). Altitudinal shifts in forest birds in a Mediterranean mountain range: causes and conservation prospects. Bird Conservation International, 1-11.
lapse_rate: used lapse rate of 0.61 C / 100 m reported by Menendez et al. 2014 for nearby site
extraction_notes: data presented in supplementary material
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: No temperature data reported in this paper, so used temperature change estimate for same site reported in Wilson et al. 2007

full_citation: Neate-Clegg, M. H., O'Brien, T. G., Mulindahabi, F., & Sekercioglu, C. H. (2020). A disconnect between upslope shifts and climate change in an Afrotropical bird community. Conservation Science and Practice, 2(11), e291.
lapse_rate: no nearby studies; used lapse rate of 0.55 C / 100 m which is typical for humid tropical mountains
extraction_notes: data for changes in elevations (limits and mean elevation) given in Table S2; presented as coefficient of linear regression of elevation vs. year; I multiplied this coefficient by 14 to estimate overall shifts
temp_change_and_exp_shift_notes: Authors have locally measured temperature, which shows a slight decrease in temperature over the study period. In contrast, CRU data show a consistent temperature increase over this study period. I use the locally measured temperature change, which is presumably a better metric for the study site
